html:
Let’s face it — landscape photography is a mix of wild patience, light-chasing, and having the right glass to match the view. And when you’re shooting with a Canon mirrorless body, the RF lens lineup is basically a candy store. Whether you’re knee-deep in wildflowers or standing on a windy cliff waiting for that perfect light, having the right lens can mean the difference between “meh” and magic. So, I rounded up the best Canon RF lenses for landscape photography — wide, long, versatile, and everything in between. Because nature doesn’t wait, and neither should your gear.

1. Best All-Round Landscape Lens: Canon RF 24-70mm F2.8L IS USM

If you could only bring one lens on your next landscape adventure, this would be the one. The RF 24-70mm f/2.8 is basically your go-to for everything from sunrise mountains to moody forest paths. It’s sharp, fast, and built like a tank (but a sexy one).

Key Features:

  • Bright f/2.8 aperture all the way through
  • Built-in 5-stop image stabilization
  • Super fast, silent Nano USM autofocus
  • Fully weather-sealed L-series build

Pros:

  • Super versatile — wide to short tele in one lens
  • Handles low light and golden hour like a champ
  • Seriously sharp across the board

Cons:

  • A bit heavy for all-day hikes
  • Not budget-friendly
  • You’ll want to baby it, even though it’s tough

Canon RF24-70mm F2.8 L is USM Lens

4.8

  • High image quality and bright f/2.8 aperture zoom RF L lens
  • Optical image stabilization of up to 5 Stops of shake correction
  • High speed, smooth and quiet autofocus with Nano USM
  • Min. Focusing distance of 0.69 ft by 0.21M (wide), 1.25 ft. by 0.38M (tele)
  • A control ring for direct setting changes
  • Lens compatible with Canon Mirorrless Cameras (EOS RP, EOS R, EOS R5, EOS R6)

2. Best for Landscapes with Scale: Canon RF 70-200mm F2.8L IS USM

This lens might look like it’s made for sports shooters, but it’s a low-key landscape killer. The 70-200mm range lets you play with perspective and isolate details you’d miss with a wide lens. Think misty mountain layers or sun-drenched ridges that go on forever.

Key Features:

  • f/2.8 across the zoom range
  • Up to 5 stops of image stabilization
  • Incredibly compact for a 70-200
  • Dual Nano USM motors = buttery smooth autofocus

Pros:

  • Compression makes everything look epic
  • Seriously compact for a telephoto
  • Sharp enough to see ants on a cliff

Cons:

  • Not exactly budget gear
  • Won’t cover ultra-wide needs
  • Not the lightest lens in your bag

Canon RF70-200mm F2.8 L is USM Lens

4.7

  • High image quality and bright f/2.8 aperture telephoto zoom RF L lens.
  • Compact and lightweight.
  • Optical image stabilization with up to 5 Stops of shake correction
  • High speed, smooth and quiet autofocus with dual Nano USM.
  • Minimum focusing distance of 2.3 ft. by 0.7 M.
  • Lens compatible with Canon Full Frame Mirrorless Cameras (EOS RP, EOS R, EOS R5, EOS R6)

3. Best Long Landscape Lens: Canon RF 100-500mm F4.5-7.1L IS USM

Ever seen a photo where a mountain looks ten times bigger than in real life? Yeah, this is how they do it. The 100-500mm is a dream for those distant peaks, lone trees, or coastal cliffs miles away. It’s big, it’s bold, and it delivers.

Key Features:

  • Zooms from 100mm all the way to 500mm
  • Optical image stabilization up to 6 stops
  • L-series ruggedness and weather sealing
  • Ultra Low Dispersion glass for crazy sharpness

Pros:

  • Epic reach without losing quality
  • Excellent sharpness throughout the zoom
  • Surprisingly lightweight for what it is

Cons:

  • That f/7.1 on the long end = lots of light needed
  • Not cheap (understatement)
  • Best used with a tripod or monopod

Canon RF100-500mm F4.5-7.1 L is USM Lens

4.7

  • High Performance L-series versatile Super-Telephoto Zoom RF Lens.
  • Optical Image Stabilization with up to 5 stops* of Shake Correction.
  • Three Image Stabilization Modes (Standard, Panning, and during exposure only) Provided for Creative Versatility.
  • High Speed, Smooth and Quiet Auto Focus with Dual Nano USM.
  • Minimum Focusing Distance of 3.0 ft. / 0.9 m**.
  • Lens compatible with Canon Full Frame Mirrorless Cameras (EOS RP, EOS R, EOS R5, EOS R6)

4. Best Ultra-Wide: Canon RF 10-20mm F4L IS STM

This lens is ridiculously wide — like, almost-comically wide. But once you shoot with it, you’ll never look back. The RF 10-20mm lets you frame up those massive skies, dramatic foregrounds, and canyon shots like a pro. Just…watch your feet. You might shoot them.

Key Features:

  • Ultra-wide 10mm starting focal length
  • Constant f/4 aperture
  • Optical IS + STM motor for silent video
  • Built to Canon’s top-tier L standards

Pros:

  • Field of view is next-level huge
  • Super sharp, even at the edges
  • Great distortion control for such a wide lens

Cons:

  • f/4 isn’t ideal for stars or low light
  • May be too wide for some compositions
  • Definitely a niche tool — not your everyday lens

Canon RF10-20mm F4 L is STM

3.5

  • Ultra-Wide 10–20mm RF Lens for Full-Frame
  • Compact & Balanced Mirrorless Design
  • Advanced Optics: 1 Super UD, 3 UD, 3 Aspheric
  • SWC & ASC Coatings to Reduce Ghosting
  • 9.8 in. Minimum Focus Distance, 0.12x Magnification

5. Best Ultra-Wide Zooms: Canon RF 15-35mm F2.8L IS USM & RF 14-35mm F4L IS USM

Can’t decide between ultra-wide and something slightly more flexible? These two are your go-tos. The 15-35mm is faster and a bit more of a beast, while the 14-35mm is lighter and easier on your back. Both are brilliant.

15-35mm f/2.8 Features:

  • Fast f/2.8 for low-light landscape magic
  • 5-stop IS for handheld shots
  • Rugged and weather-sealed
  • Silent, fast Nano USM motor

14-35mm f/4 Features:

  • Even wider at 14mm
  • Lighter and more travel-friendly
  • Same excellent IS
  • Excellent color and clarity

Pros (both):

  • Wide, sharp, and made to last
  • Perfect for dramatic skies and close foregrounds
  • Ideal for video as well

Cons (15-35mm):

  • On the heavy side
  • Expensive (but amazing)
  • Takes up a decent chunk of bag space

Cons (14-35mm):

  • f/4 means it’s not great for astrophotography
  • Slight edge softness at 14mm
  • Still not exactly cheap

Canon RF15-35mm F2.8 L is USM Lens

4.7

  • High image quality and bright f/2.8 wide-angle zoom RF L lens
  • Optical image stabilization of up to 5 Stops* of shake correction
  • High speed, smooth and quiet auto focus with Nano USM
  • Minimum focusing distance of 0.92 ft./0.28M
  • Control ring for direct setting changes

6. Best for Versatility: Canon RF 24-105mm F4L IS USM

The 24-105mm is that friend who’s good at everything. Need to go wide? No problem. Need to zoom in a bit? It’s got you. It’s not the fastest lens out there, but if you’re traveling light and want one lens to rule them all, this is it.

Key Features:

  • Covers everything from wide to medium tele
  • Constant f/4
  • Built-in IS (up to 5 stops)
  • Customizable control ring

Pros:

  • Killer walk-around lens
  • Lightweight and balanced
  • Handles most landscape situations with ease

Cons:

  • f/4 can feel limiting in low light
  • Not quite as sharp as primes
  • Can’t isolate as well as faster glass

Canon RF 24-105mm f/4L IS USM Lens

4.6

  • Compact, high-quality Lens with broad zoom range for the EOS R system
  • Bright, constant f/4.0 zoom Lens
  • First L-Series Lens with Nano USM
  • Control ring for direct setting changes
  • Optical image stabilization at up to 5 Stops* of shake Correction

7. Best Hybrid Wide-Angle Primes: RF 24mm F1.4L VCM & RF 20mm F1.4L VCM

If you’re a fan of shooting with primes — or just love low-light landscape work — these two are straight-up magic. Both are razor sharp, compact, and perfect for everything from milky way shots to wide environmental scenes with dreamy bokeh.

Key Features:

  • Bright f/1.4 aperture = nighttime wizardry
  • VCM + Nano USM for dual autofocus magic
  • Built tough with weather sealing
  • Gorgeous color rendering

Pros:

  • Stunning in low light or night sky conditions
  • Tack-sharp across the frame
  • Compact, especially for f/1.4

Cons:

  • You lose zoom flexibility
  • Premium price for a fixed focal
  • Might take some time to master composition

Canon RF24mm F1.4 L VCM

5

  • 24mm L-Series Hybrid Lens with Manual Iris Ring
  • Nano USM + VCM Dual Focus System for Video
  • Minimal Focus Breathing (<1% with Correction)
  • ASC & Fluorine Coating Reduce Ghosting/Flare
  • Weather-Sealed, Durable L-Series Build

So there you have it — the ultimate Canon RF lens dream team for landscape lovers. Whether you’re a dawn chaser, a star shooter, or someone who just really, really loves mountains, there’s a lens here that fits your style and your vibe. You’ve got wide-angle beasts, long-reach monsters, and those ever-trusty workhorse zooms that do a bit of everything.

At the end of the day, landscapes are about telling stories — and the right lens helps you tell them beautifully. Some lenses will stretch your budget (and maybe your shoulder muscles), but they’ll also stretch your creative possibilities. So whether you’re shooting a soft, misty morning or a dramatic cliffside sunset, you’ll have the right tools to make the moment last.

Now get out there and create something incredible — nature’s putting on a show, and you’ve got the perfect front-row seat.
